results.title: The Boys who came home: recollections of Gallipoli
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Harvey Broadbent and Paul Montgomery
results.brief_description: This documentary features interviews with veterans of the Gallipoli campaign. Through recollections, photographs and archival film, the history of Australia’s involvement in World war I is explored. The video includes interviews with Turkish veterans of the battle who offer their own stories of tragic loss. The documentary concludes by following a group of Australian veterans who return to the Turkish coast to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the Gallipoli campaign. The video includes footage of the official Dawn Service at Gallipoli on the 75th Anniversary of the dawn landing attended by Prime Minister Hawke.

results.title: The Boys in the band
results.creator_credit: Leo Productions, Mart Crowley and William Friedkin
results.brief_description: Mart Crowley’s landmark (it was the first Hollywood film to feature an entire cast of gay characters) time capsule of the sixties gay scene has dated well, offering an unflinching glimpse at the lives of a group of gay men as they grapple with relationships, aging and internalized homophobia. Adapted by Crowley from his own play (featuring the original stage cast) and directed by William Friedkin, ‘The Boys in the band’ confines its drama to a single, claustrophobic night where a group of friends gather to celebrate the birthday of the wry, razor tongued Harold (Leonard Frey). The party takes a turn for the worse when Michael,(Kenneth Nelson) the party’s host, has an unexpected visitor, an old heterosexual college friend who is struggling with his own sexuality. The booze soaked party soon turns into a night of psychosexual torture, vicious games and brutal confession. Friedkin came under fire at the time (as he would again with 1980’s ‘Cruising’) from various gay activist who deemed the film homophobic and an affront to the affirmation politics that were very much part of the gay scene at the time, singling out lines such as “show me a happy homosexual and I’ll show you a gay corpse”. Cast includes Frederick Combs, Cliff Gorman, Reuben Greene, Laurence Luckinbill, Keith Prentice, Robert La Tourneaux and Peter White.

results.title: The Boys from Brazil
results.creator_credit: Circle Productions, Fox, Martin Richards, Stanley O'Toole and Franklin J. Schaffner
results.brief_description: A terrifying thriller based on the best-selling novel by Ira Levin. Living in South America, Dr. Josef Mengele, (Gregory Peck) gathers a group of former Nazis in his plan to clone Hitler. Barry Kohler, (Steve Guttenburg), informs famed Nazi hunter Ezra Lieberman, (Laurence Olivier). Kohler’s murder incites Lieberman to investigate, and he begins to unravel a conspiracy which leads to Mengele. Mengele has cloned 94 Hitlers, and is killing their fathers in order to simulate Hitler’s own youth. Suddenly, the terrifying extent of Mengele’s plan is revealed. Also stars James Mason, Denholm Elliot and Lilli Palmer.

results.title: The Boys from Boise
results.brief_description: There were a few original musicals written for TV in the 1940s, but viewers were few and these shows are essentially forgotten. Most experts agree that the first original televised musical was The Boys From Boise, broadcast by the DuMont Network in 1944.

results.description: There were a few original musicals written for television in the 1940s, but viewers were few and these shows are essentially forgotten. Most experts agree that the first original televised musical was The Boys From Boise, broadcast by the DuMont Network on Sept. 28, 1944. It had a score by Sam Medoff and told the story of a troupe of showgirls stranded on an Idaho ranch. Although well received, it boasted no stars, turned out no hit songs and started no trends. - musicals101.com

results.title: The Boys' own choice
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Denise Eriksen and Bruce Permezel
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Problem with men”.
This episode in the “Problem with men” series traces the movement to increase awareness of men’s health. In Daylesford, Victoria, we witness a successful men’s health night presented by GPS’s, chemists and dignitaries. Meanwhile, in Dallas, Texas, we visit the first Male Health Centre - the layout of the building, the clientele they attract. The centre is also involved in the regular, on-site health screenings for all male American Airlines employees, a process which has proved very successful in identifying major illnesses such as cancer. Presented by John Clarke and Bryan Dawe.

results.title: The Boys
results.creator_credit: Arenafilm, Australian Film Commission, Premium Movie Partnership, SBS Independant, Robert Connolly, John Maynard and Rowan Woods
results.brief_description: Adapted from Gordon Graham’s award-winning 1991 play by Stephen Sewell, which was inspired by the horrific Anita Cobby murder case, ‘The Boys’ is an amazing directorial debut from Rowan Woods. The film follows the events that occur after Brett Sprague (David Wenham), is released from prison after serving time for assaulting the manager of a local bottle shop. Brett’s presence creates a constant sense of tension as everybody in the house - his mother Sandra (Lynette Curran), his two brothers Glenn (John Polson) and Steve (Anthony Hayes), his girlfriend Michelle (a fantastic performance from Toni Collete), Glenn’s wife Jackie (Jeanette Cronin), Steve’s pregnant girlfriend Nola (Anna Lise) and Sandra’s boyfriend George (Pete Smith) - treads carefully around Brett’s restrained anger. The film ocassionally flashes forward to the arrest and trial of the three brothers, building up the suspense as we wait for Brett to explode into violence. The actual murder is never shown but the suspense of the film and the atmosphere created by a superb cast makes this a chilling experience. The film won 4 awards at the 1998 AFI Awards - Best Director, Best Supporting Actor, Best Supporting Actress and Best Screenplay Adapted from Another Source”. Cinematography by Tristan Milani.

results.title: The Boyhood of Thomas Edison
results.brief_description: Dramatised incidents from the boyhood of Edison - his sitting on eggs to hatch them, his early experiments with chemicals and electricity, the newspaper he published on a train, provide an insight into his character traits. His curiosity, persistence, ingenuity, and his ability to learn through observation, qualities which later helped him change the world.

results.title: The Boy who turned yellow
results.creator_credit: Children's Film Foundation, Roger Cherrill and Michael Powell
results.brief_description: John (Mark Dightam) and his class go on a school trip to the Tower of London. While he is there he loses his pet mouse and vows to return and find her later. Back in school, he is not very attentive and falls asleep during a lesson about electricity so his teacher sends him home. On the ‘tube’ there is a sudden flash and John, the train and everyone on it has turned yellow. With the help of Nick - short for ‘Electronic’ (Robert Eddison) John learns about electricity, invades the Tower of London and saves his pet mouse…or was it a dream! Original story and screenplay by Emeric Pressburger. Cast also includes Helen Weir and Brian Worth.

results.title: The Boy who turned off
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Jerry Krepakevich, Michael Scott and Larry Kurnarsky
results.brief_description: An intimate portrait of a family’s struggle to cope with an autistic son. The film examines the effects of an endless cycle of successes and failures, the frustration’s of seeking treatment for a problem that still eludes definition, and the painful uncertainty of what the future will bring. A powerful, thought-provoking film for anyone who seeks to understand autism or the disabled person’s relations with family. Award: New York

results.title: The Boy who stopped talking = De Jongen die niet meet praatt
results.creator_credit: Bos Bros Film - TV Productions, Burny Bos and Ben Sombogaart
results.brief_description: The Boy who stopped talking is the story of Memo, (Ercan Orhan) a nine-year-old child living in eastern Turkey in a small traditional Kurdish village. Memo has the important roles in the village of postman, which also involves reading the mail to the illiterate, and shepherd. He lives there with his mother and young sister whilst his father works in The Netherlands in a shipyard. Memo’s happy, innocent existence is thrown into chaos one day when his father decides to relocate the family to The Netherlands to escape the dangers of the oncoming war in Turkey. Memo responds to this unhappy event by deciding to stop talking. A subplot involving illegal immigrants exposes their vulnerability and their exploitation at the hands of shady business owners. This gently observed film explores the effects that cultural dislocation has on children and their families. A local boy and classmate, Jeroen, tries to befriend Memo and aid his assimilation into school life. Memo resists his father’s imploring to break his silence, longing for his village, which is being ravaged by war. In Turkish and Dutch with English subtitles.
